Return a comprehensive summary of the current Java test landscape including:

- Any performance-related configurations
- Existing test utilities or patterns

input.userQuery: Maven plugin testing best practices integration testing

content.text:
Below are some documentation sections that could be relevant to the user request. Read through them carefully. You don't have to use them to answer the user query, but they might help. Do not assume knowledge about nx, its configuration and options. Instead, base your replies on the provided metadata and these documentation sections.

- Enforce Organizational Best Practices with a Local Plugin
# Enforce Organizational Best Practices with a Local Plugin Every repository has a unique set of conventions and best practices that developers need to learn in order to write code that integrates well with the rest of the code base. It is important to document those best practices, but developers don't always read the documentation and even if they have read the documentation, they don't consistently follow the documentation every time they perform a task. Nx allows you to encode these best practices in code generators that have been tailored to your specific repository. In this tutorial, we will create a generator that helps enforce the follow best practices: * Every project in this repository should use Vitest for unit tests. * Every project in this repository should be tagged with a `scope:*` tag that is chosen from the list of available scopes. * Projects should be placed in folders that match the scope that they are assigned. * Vitest should clear mocks before running tests.
- Testing your plugin
## Testing your plugin One of the biggest benefits that the Nx Plugin package provides is support for E2E and unit testing. When the E2E app runs, a temporary E2E directory is created in the root of the workspace. This directory is a blank Nx workspace, and will have the plugin's built package installed locally.
- Writing and running e2e tests
## Writing and running e2e tests When setting up the workspace, you should also have gotten a `my-plugin-e2e` package. This package contains the e2e tests for your plugin, and can be run with the following command: ```shell npx nx e2e my-plugin-e2e ``` Have a look at some of the example tests that were generated for you. When running these tests, * the local registry will be started automatically * a new version of the packages will be deployed * then your test commands will be run (usually triggering processes that setup the workspace, just like the user would type into a command line interface) * once the test commands have finished, the local registry will be stopped again and cleaned up
- Included plugins
## Included plugins The plugin contains the following rule configurations divided into sub-plugins.

input.description: Research Maven plugin testing
input.prompt:
I need to research Maven plugin testing best practices, specifically looking for:

1. Search for Maven official documentation on plugin testing approaches
2. Look for Maven Testing Harness or maven-plugin-testing-harness usage
3. Find information about integration testing vs unit testing for Maven plugins
4. Look for examples of testing Maven plugins with minimal mocking
5. Search for maven-invoker-plugin usage for integration tests
6. Check if there are any existing Maven plugin test examples in this codebase
7. Look for pom.xml configurations related to plugin testing

Focus on finding the official Maven recommended approaches that minimize mocking and provide real integration testing capabilities.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0
         http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

    <groupId>io.quarkus</groupId>
    <artifactId>maven-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>999-SNAPSHOT</version>
    <packaging>maven-plugin</packaging>

    <properties>
        <maven.compiler.source>11</maven.compiler.source>
        <maven.compiler.target>11</maven.compiler.target>
        <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
        <maven.version>3.8.8</maven.version>
    </properties>

    <dependencies>
        <!-- Maven Plugin API -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-plugin-api</artifactId>
            <version>${maven.version}</version>
        </dependency>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugin-tools</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-plugin-annotations</artifactId>
            <version>3.9.0</version>
            <scope>provided</scope>
        </dependency>
        
        <!-- Maven Core for MavenSession -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-core</artifactId>
            <version>${maven.version}</version>
        </dependency>
        
        <!-- Maven Project -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-model</artifactId>
            <version>${maven.version}</version>
        </dependency>
        
        <!-- JSON output -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>com.google.code.gson</groupId>
            <artifactId>gson</artifactId>
            <version>2.10.1</version>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>

    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.11.0</version>
                <configuration>
                    <source>11</source>
                    <target>11</target>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-plugin-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.9.0</version>
                <configuration>
                    <goalPrefix>nx</goalPrefix>
                </configuration>
                <executions>
                    <execution>
                        <id>default-descriptor</id>
                        <goals>
                            <goal>descriptor</goal>
                        </goals>
                    </execution>
                </executions>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>
</project>

I found the official Apache Maven Plugin Testing Harness documentation. Here are the key resources:

## Official Documentation

The Maven Plugin Testing Harness provides mechanisms to manage tests on Mojo and has comprehensive official documentation available at:

- **Main Documentation**: https://maven.apache.org/plugin-testing/maven-plugin-testing-harness/
- **Getting Started Guide**: https://maven.apache.org/plugin-testing/maven-plugin-testing-harness/getting-started/index.html
- **FAQ**: https://maven.apache.org/plugin-testing/maven-plugin-testing-harness/faq.html

## Key Setup Information

To use the testing harness, add maven-plugin-testing-harness as a dependency in your pom with test scope:

The current version is 4.0.0-alpha-2, and the dependency configuration is:

```xml
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugin-testing</groupId>
    <artifactId>maven-plugin-testing-harness</artifactId>
    <version>4.0.0-alpha-2</version>
    <scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
```

## Testing Approaches

The documentation shows two main approaches:

1. **Traditional JUnit 3 Style**: Create test classes that extend AbstractMojoTestCase from maven-plugin-testing-harness

2. **Modern JUnit 4+ Style**: Use the MojoRule with JUnit 4+ annotations, which provides more flexibility and allows you to use the @WithoutMojo annotation to skip rule executions when not needed

## Additional Resources

- **Source Code**: Available on GitHub at https://github.com/apache/maven-plugin-testing
- The best way to start is to read the cookbook "How to use Maven Plugin Testing Harness"
- Maven Plugin Testing Harness 2.0+ requires Maven 3.0 for the testing environment, though your mojos can still be compatible with Maven 2.x

The official documentation provides complete examples and detailed instructions for setting up and writing tests for Maven plugins using the testing harness.

Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about the Apache Maven Invoker Plugin and its use for integration tests. Here's what I found:

## Apache Maven Invoker Plugin for Integration Tests

The Maven Invoker Plugin is particularly handy to perform integration tests for other Maven plugins. The Invoker Plugin can be employed to run a set of test projects that have been designed to assert certain features of the plugin under test.

### Key Features

The Invoker Plugin is used to run a set of Maven projects. The plugin can determine whether each project execution is successful, and optionally can verify the output generated from a given project execution.

### Main Goals

The plugin provides several goals for integration testing:

- invoker:install copies the project artifacts and dependencies of the main build into a dedicated local repository to prepare the execution of the selected sub projects in an isolated environment.

- invoker:run runs a set of Maven projects in a directory and verifies the result. This is equivalent to running both invoker:integration-test and invoker:verify.

- invoker:integration-test binds by default to the lifecycle phase: integration-test.

- invoker:verify checks the results of maven-invoker-plugin based integration tests and fails the build if any tests failed, and binds by default to the lifecycle phase: verify.

### Basic Usage

The plugin is commonly used to run and verify integration tests for a project, say a Maven plugin. This is done using the invoker:run goal.(no content)The invoker:run goal will execute during the phase integration-test and will use the configured include/exclude patterns to search the directory src/it for IT POMs. Every directory where an IT POM is found will be copied over to target/it.

### Configuration Example

A typical integration test setup includes:
- Project structure with integration tests in `src/it/`
- Configuration for cloning projects to a target directory
- Local repository setup for isolated testing
- Post-build hook scripts for verification

It is essential that you provide some form of integration testing for your projects and the Invoker Plugin tries to make it easy for you to create integration tests for your Maven Plugins, new Lifecycles, or any other type of Maven component that you've created.

The plugin supports advanced features like parallel execution, custom settings, filtering of project files, and post-build verification scripts to ensure comprehensive integration testing of Maven projects.

Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about Maven Plugin Testing Harness and its approach to integration testing with minimal mocking.

## Maven Plugin Testing Harness Overview

The Maven Plugin Testing Harness provides mechanisms to manage tests on Mojos, i.e. by pre-constructing the Plexus components, providing stub objects for Maven functionality such as projects, and populating fields from an XML file that resembles the plugin configuration in the POM.

## Unit Testing vs Integration Testing Philosophy

A unit test attempts to verify a mojo as an isolated unit, by mocking out the rest of the Maven environment. A mojo unit test does not attempt to run your plugin in the context of a real Maven build. Unit tests are designed to be fast.(no content)This testing library is NOT designed for integration or functional testing: maven-invoker-plugin is the way to go if you need it, which gives you a complete Maven environment at the cost of more resources and time consuptions.

## Minimal Mocking Approach

The Maven Plugin Testing Harness employs a "minimal mocking" strategy by:

1. **Pre-constructing Plexus Components**: by pre-constructing the Plexus components, providing stub objects for Maven functionality such as projects

2. **Leveraging Real Maven Context**: My plugin mojo test class leverages maven-plugin-test-harness to build the complete maven environment with all pom config, plexus container context and repo access.

3. **Using AbstractMojoTestCase**: This class should extend AbstractMojoTestCase from maven-plugin-testing-harness.

## Implementation Examples

### Basic Setup
As usual, just add maven-plugin-testing-harness as following in your pom. Be sure to specify test scope.

### JUnit 4 Alternative with MojoRule
Alternatively to extending AbstractMojoTestCase and when using Junit-4.10 ff., you may use a MojoRule, which just embeds an AbstractMojoTestCase. When you do not need the functionality in every test method, you may use the @WithoutMojo annotation to skip rule executions.

### Modern Testing Approaches
These dependencies can be Mockito mocks or instances of the actual model classes. If a particular test does not access the injected field  that is, it's only injected to fulfill the constructor signature  you can usually also pass null as the value of that argument.

## Alternative Solutions

For more comprehensive integration testing, the search results mention several alternatives:

1. **Takari Plugin Testing**: The library provides a superior alternative to maven-plugin-testing-harness and maven-verifier and invoker based test setups.

2. **Maven Invoker Plugin**: For full integration testing scenarios where you need a complete Maven environment.

The Maven Plugin Testing Harness strikes a balance between full mocking (which would be too isolated) and full integration testing (which would be too slow), providing a "minimal mocking" approach that gives you enough Maven context to test your plugin effectively while keeping tests fast and focused.

The Maven Plugin Testing Harness provides mechanisms to manage tests on Mojos, i.e. by pre-constructing the Plexus components, providing stub objects for Maven functionality such as projects, and populating fields from an XML file that resembles the plugin configuration in the POM.

## Unit Testing vs Integration Testing Philosophy

A unit test attempts to verify a mojo as an isolated unit, by mocking out the rest of the Maven environment. A mojo unit test does not attempt to run your plugin in the context of a real Maven build. Unit tests are designed to be fast.(no content)This testing library is NOT designed for integration or functional testing: maven-invoker-plugin is the way to go if you need it, which gives you a complete Maven environment at the cost of more resources and time consuptions.

## Minimal Mocking Approach

The Maven Plugin Testing Harness employs a "minimal mocking" strategy by:

1. **Pre-constructing Plexus Components**: by pre-constructing the Plexus components, providing stub objects for Maven functionality such as projects

2. **Leveraging Real Maven Context**: My plugin mojo test class leverages maven-plugin-test-harness to build the complete maven environment with all pom config, plexus container context and repo access.

3. **Using AbstractMojoTestCase**: This class should extend AbstractMojoTestCase from maven-plugin-testing-harness.

## Implementation Examples

### Basic Setup
As usual, just add maven-plugin-testing-harness as following in your pom. Be sure to specify test scope.

### JUnit 4 Alternative with MojoRule
Alternatively to extending AbstractMojoTestCase and when using Junit-4.10 ff., you may use a MojoRule, which just embeds an AbstractMojoTestCase. When you do not need the functionality in every test method, you may use the @WithoutMojo annotation to skip rule executions.

### Modern Testing Approaches
These dependencies can be Mockito mocks or instances of the actual model classes. If a particular test does not access the injected field  that is, it's only injected to fulfill the constructor signature  you can usually also pass null as the value of that argument.

## Alternative Solutions

For more comprehensive integration testing, the search results mention several alternatives:

1. **Takari Plugin Testing**: The library provides a superior alternative to maven-plugin-testing-harness and maven-verifier and invoker based test setups.

2. **Maven Invoker Plugin**: For full integration testing scenarios where you need a complete Maven environment.

The Maven Plugin Testing Harness strikes a balance between full mocking (which would be too isolated) and full integration testing (which would be too slow), providing a "minimal mocking" approach that gives you enough Maven context to test your plugin effectively while keeping tests fast and focused.

```java
}
```

- maven-invoker-plugin: Enables invoking Maven and running BeanShell/Groovy tests

Best Practices:
- Use unit tests as primary testing method
- Include some integration/functional tests
- Choose testing approach based on specific plugin requirements

content.content:
Here's a concise guide to setting up Maven Invoker Plugin for integration testing:

Project Structure Recommendation:
```
./
+- pom.xml
+- src/
   +- it/
      +- settings.xml
      +- first-it/
      |  +- pom.xml
      +- second-it/
         +- pom.xml
         +- invoker.properties
         +- verify.bsh
```

Plugin Configuration Example:
```xml
<plugin>
  <artifactId>maven-invoker-plugin</artifactId>
  <version>3.9.0</version>
  <configuration>
    <cloneProjectsTo>${project.build.directory}/it</cloneProjectsTo>
    <settingsFile>src/it/settings.xml</settingsFile>
    <localRepositoryPath>${project.build.directory}/local-repo</localRepositoryPath>
    <postBuildHookScript>verify</postBuildHookScript>
  </configuration>
  <executions>
    <execution>
      <goals>
        <goal>install</goal>
        <goal>run</goal>
      </goals>
    </execution>
  </executions>
</plugin>
```

Key Steps:
1. Place integration test projects in `src/it/`
2. Configure plugin in project's POM
3. Run tests with `mvn integration-test`

Additional Features:
- Run specific tests: `mvn invoker:run -Dinvoker.test=*MWAR*,simple*`
- Use `invoker.properties` for test-specific configurations
- Optional post-build verification scripts

The plugin automatically stages artifacts, filters POMs, and executes integration tests with detailed logging.

content.text: Now let me create comprehensive notes about Maven plugin testing best practices:

input.content:
# Maven Plugin Testing Best Practices Research

## Overview
This document compiles research on Maven plugin testing approaches, focusing on official Apache Maven recommendations that minimize mocking and provide real integration testing capabilities.

## Testing Strategy Philosophy

### Unit Testing vs Integration Testing
- **Unit Testing**: Tests mojo as "isolated unit" by mocking Maven environment
  - Fast execution
  - Focuses on individual component verification
  - Uses maven-plugin-testing-harness
- **Integration Testing**: Tests plugin in "real Maven build" context
  - Slower but comprehensive
  - Catches environment-specific issues
  - Uses maven-invoker-plugin or maven-verifier

### Apache Maven Recommendation
"The general wisdom is that your code should be mostly tested with unit tests, but should also have some functional tests."

## Maven Plugin Testing Harness (Unit Testing)

### Purpose and Philosophy
- Pre-constructs Plexus components
- Provides stub objects for Maven functionality (projects, etc.)
- Populates fields from XML configuration resembling plugin POM
- **Minimal Mocking Approach**: Not full mocking, but provides enough Maven context

### Setup Dependencies
```xml
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugin-testing</groupId>
    <artifactId>maven-plugin-testing-harness</artifactId>
    <version>4.0.0-alpha-2</version>
    <scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
<dependency>
    <groupId>junit</groupId>
    <artifactId>junit</artifactId>
    <version>4.13.2</version>
    <scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
```

### Implementation Approaches

#### Option 1: AbstractMojoTestCase (Traditional)
```java
public class MyMojoTest extends AbstractMojoTestCase {
    
    protected void setUp() throws Exception {
        super.setUp();
    }
    
    protected void tearDown() throws Exception {
        super.tearDown();
    }
    
    public void testMojoGoal() throws Exception {
        File pom = getTestFile("src/test/resources/unit/project-to-test/pom.xml");
        MyMojo mojo = (MyMojo) lookupMojo("mygoal", pom);
        assertNotNull(mojo);
        mojo.execute();
        // Assertions
    }
}
```

#### Option 2: MojoRule (JUnit 4.10+, Recommended)
```java
public class MyMojoTest {
    @Rule
    public MojoRule rule = new MojoRule() {
        @Override
        protected void before() throws Throwable {
            // Setup
        }
        @Override
        protected void after() {
            // Cleanup
        }
    };
    
    @Test
    public void testMojoGoal() throws Exception {
        File pom = rule.getTestFile("src/test/resources/unit/project-to-test/pom.xml");
        assertNotNull(pom);
        assertTrue(pom.exists());
        
        MyMojo mojo = (MyMojo) rule.lookupMojo("mygoal", pom);
        assertNotNull(mojo);
        mojo.execute();
        // Assertions
    }
    
    @Test
    @WithoutMojo  // Skip rule execution for this test
    public void testUtilityMethod() {
        // Test that doesn't need Maven context
    }
}
```

### Test Project Structure
```
src/test/resources/unit/project-to-test/
 pom.xml          # Test project POM with plugin configuration
 src/            # Optional test project sources
```

### Test Project POM Example
```xml
<project>
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
    <groupId>test</groupId>
    <artifactId>test-project</artifactId>
    <version>1.0</version>
    
    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>your.group</groupId>
                <artifactId>your-plugin</artifactId>
                <configuration>
                    <parameter>value</parameter>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>
</project>
```

## Maven Invoker Plugin (Integration Testing)

### Purpose
- Runs complete Maven builds with your plugin
- Tests plugin in real Maven environment
- Handles artifact staging and repository isolation

### Project Structure
```
./
 pom.xml
 src/
     it/
         settings.xml         # Optional global settings
         first-integration-test/
            pom.xml
            invoker.properties  # Test-specific config
            verify.bsh          # Post-build verification
         second-integration-test/
             pom.xml
             verify.groovy
```

### Plugin Configuration
```xml
<plugin>
    <artifactId>maven-invoker-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>3.9.0</version>
    <configuration>
        <cloneProjectsTo>${project.build.directory}/it</cloneProjectsTo>
        <settingsFile>src/it/settings.xml</settingsFile>
        <localRepositoryPath>${project.build.directory}/local-repo</localRepositoryPath>
        <postBuildHookScript>verify</postBuildHookScript>
        <goals>
            <goal>clean</goal>
            <goal>compile</goal>
        </goals>
    </configuration>
    <executions>
        <execution>
            <goals>
                <goal>install</goal>  <!-- Stage artifacts -->
                <goal>run</goal>      <!-- Run tests -->
            </goals>
        </execution>
    </executions>
</plugin>
```

### Invoker Properties Example
```properties
# invoker.properties
invoker.goals = clean compile your-plugin:your-goal
invoker.buildResult = success
invoker.mavenOpts = -Xmx512m
```

### Verification Script Example (BeanShell)
```java
// verify.bsh
import java.io.*;

File expectedFile = new File(basedir, "target/generated-file.txt");
if (!expectedFile.exists()) {
    throw new RuntimeException("Expected file not found: " + expectedFile);
}

String content = FileUtils.fileRead(expectedFile);
if (!content.contains("expected-content")) {
    throw new RuntimeException("File does not contain expected content");
}

return true;
```

## Alternative Testing Frameworks

### Takari Plugin Testing
- Superior alternative to maven-plugin-testing-harness
- Better integration with modern testing practices
- Reduced boilerplate

### Maven Verifier

# Maven Plugin Testing Best Practices Research

## Overview
This document compiles research on Maven plugin testing approaches, focusing on official Apache Maven recommendations that minimize mocking and provide real integration testing capabilities.

## Testing Strategy Philosophy

### Unit Testing vs Integration Testing
- **Unit Testing**: Tests mojo as "isolated unit" by mocking Maven environment
  - Fast execution
  - Focuses on individual component verification
  - Uses maven-plugin-testing-harness
- **Integration Testing**: Tests plugin in "real Maven build" context
  - Slower but comprehensive
  - Catches environment-specific issues
  - Uses maven-invoker-plugin or maven-verifier

### Apache Maven Recommendation
"The general wisdom is that your code should be mostly tested with unit tests, but should also have some functional tests."

## Maven Plugin Testing Harness (Unit Testing)

### Purpose and Philosophy
- Pre-constructs Plexus components
- Provides stub objects for Maven functionality (projects, etc.)
- Populates fields from XML configuration resembling plugin POM
- **Minimal Mocking Approach**: Not full mocking, but provides enough Maven context

### Setup Dependencies
```xml
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugin-testing</groupId>
    <artifactId>maven-plugin-testing-harness</artifactId>
    <version>4.0.0-alpha-2</version>
    <scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
<dependency>
    <groupId>junit</groupId>
    <artifactId>junit</artifactId>
    <version>4.13.2</version>
    <scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
```

### Implementation Approaches

#### Option 1: AbstractMojoTestCase (Traditional)
```java
public class MyMojoTest extends AbstractMojoTestCase {
    
    protected void setUp() throws Exception {
        super.setUp();
    }
    
    protected void tearDown() throws Exception {
        super.tearDown();
    }
    
    public void testMojoGoal() throws Exception {
        File pom = getTestFile("src/test/resources/unit/project-to-test/pom.xml");
        MyMojo mojo = (MyMojo) lookupMojo("mygoal", pom);
        assertNotNull(mojo);
        mojo.execute();
        // Assertions
    }
}
```

#### Option 2: MojoRule (JUnit 4.10+, Recommended)
```java
public class MyMojoTest {
    @Rule
    public MojoRule rule = new MojoRule() {
        @Override
        protected void before() throws Throwable {
            // Setup
        }
        @Override
        protected void after() {
            // Cleanup
        }
    };
    
    @Test
    public void testMojoGoal() throws Exception {
        File pom = rule.getTestFile("src/test/resources/unit/project-to-test/pom.xml");
        assertNotNull(pom);
        assertTrue(pom.exists());
        
        MyMojo mojo = (MyMojo) rule.lookupMojo("mygoal", pom);
        assertNotNull(mojo);
        mojo.execute();
        // Assertions
    }
    
    @Test
    @WithoutMojo  // Skip rule execution for this test
    public void testUtilityMethod() {
        // Test that doesn't need Maven context
    }
}
```

### Test Project Structure
```
src/test/resources/unit/project-to-test/
 pom.xml          # Test project POM with plugin configuration
 src/            # Optional test project sources
```

### Test Project POM Example
```xml
<project>
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
    <groupId>test</groupId>
    <artifactId>test-project</artifactId>
    <version>1.0</version>
    
    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>your.group</groupId>
                <artifactId>your-plugin</artifactId>
                <configuration>
                    <parameter>value</parameter>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>
</project>
```

## Maven Invoker Plugin (Integration Testing)

### Purpose
- Runs complete Maven builds with your plugin
- Tests plugin in real Maven environment
- Handles artifact staging and repository isolation

### Project Structure
```
./
 pom.xml
 src/
     it/
         settings.xml         # Optional global settings
         first-integration-test/
            pom.xml
            invoker.properties  # Test-specific config
            verify.bsh          # Post-build verification
         second-integration-test/
             pom.xml
             verify.groovy
```

### Plugin Configuration
```xml
<plugin>
    <artifactId>maven-invoker-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>3.9.0</version>
    <configuration>
        <cloneProjectsTo>${project.build.directory}/it</cloneProjectsTo>
        <settingsFile>src/it/settings.xml</settingsFile>
        <localRepositoryPath>${project.build.directory}/local-repo</localRepositoryPath>
        <postBuildHookScript>verify</postBuildHookScript>
        <goals>
            <goal>clean</goal>
            <goal>compile</goal>
        </goals>
    </configuration>
    <executions>
        <execution>
            <goals>
                <goal>install</goal>  <!-- Stage artifacts -->
                <goal>run</goal>      <!-- Run tests -->
            </goals>
        </execution>
    </executions>
</plugin>
```

### Invoker Properties Example
```properties
# invoker.properties
invoker.goals = clean compile your-plugin:your-goal
invoker.buildResult = success
invoker.mavenOpts = -Xmx512m
```

### Verification Script Example (BeanShell)
```java
// verify.bsh
import java.io.*;

File expectedFile = new File(basedir, "target/generated-file.txt");
if (!expectedFile.exists()) {
    throw new RuntimeException("Expected file not found: " + expectedFile);
}

String content = FileUtils.fileRead(expectedFile);
if (!content.contains("expected-content")) {
    throw new RuntimeException("File does not contain expected content");
}

return true;
```

## Alternative Testing Frameworks

### Takari Plugin Testing
- Superior alternative to maven-plugin-testing-harness
- Better integration with modern testing practices
- Reduced boilerplate

### Maven Verifier
- Lower-level API for launching Maven
- Good for custom testing scenarios
- More complex setup but more control

## Best Practices Summary

### For Current Maven Plugin Project

1. **Start with Unit Tests** using maven-plugin-testing-harness
   - Use MojoRule approach (JUnit 4+)
   - Create minimal test POMs in src/test/resources
   - Test core mojo functionality

2. **Add Integration Tests** using maven-invoker-plugin
   - Test realistic scenarios
   - Verify plugin works in complete Maven builds
   - Test edge cases and error conditions

3. **Recommended Test Mix**
   - 70-80% unit tests (fast feedback)
   - 20-30% integration tests (comprehensive validation)

### Current Project Status
- Maven plugin exists at `/maven-plugin/`
- No test infrastructure currently in place
- Ready for implementing comprehensive testing strategy

## Implementation Plan

1. Add testing dependencies to maven-plugin/pom.xml
2. Create unit test structure with MojoRule
3. Set up integration test framework with maven-invoker-plugin
4. Create test projects for various scenarios
5. Implement verification scripts for integration tests

## Key Advantages of This Approach

- **Minimal Mocking**: Testing harness provides real Maven context
- **Real Integration**: Invoker plugin tests complete Maven builds  
- **Official Support**: Both are Apache Maven official tools
- **Comprehensive Coverage**: Unit tests for speed, integration tests for completeness
- **Maintainable**: Well-documented, standard approaches

```java
import org.apache.maven.plugin.testing.MojoRule;
```

```xml
<!-- src/it/simple-project/pom.xml -->
<project>

                    <execution>
                        <goals>

                        </goals>
                    </execution>
                </executions>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>

</project>
```

```properties
# src/it/simple-project/invoker.properties
invoker.goals = clean compile nx:analyze
invoker.buildResult = success
```

```java
// src/it/simple-project/verify.bsh
import java.io.*;
import java.util.*;
import com.google.gson.*;

// Verify output file exists
File outputFile = new File(basedir, "nx-project-graph.json");
if (!outputFile.exists()) {
    throw new RuntimeException("nx-project-graph.json not found");
}

// Parse and validate JSON structure
String content = new String(Files.readAllBytes(outputFile.toPath()));
JsonObject graph = JsonParser.parseString(content).getAsJsonObject();

// Validate required fields
if (!graph.has("projects")) {
    throw new RuntimeException("Missing 'projects' field in output");
}

if (!graph.has("dependencies")) {
    throw new RuntimeException("Missing 'dependencies' field in output");
}

// Validate project exists
JsonObject projects = graph.getAsJsonObject("projects");
if (!projects.has("simple-project")) {
    throw new RuntimeException("Project 'simple-project' not found in graph");
}

System.out.println("Integration test passed successfully!");
return true;
```

### Phase 3: Advanced Testing Scenarios

#### 1. Error Handling Tests
- Invalid POM structures
- Missing dependencies
- Network failures (if applicable)
- Permissions issues

#### 2. Performance Tests
- Large multi-module projects
- Deep dependency hierarchies
- Memory usage validation

#### 3. Real-world Scenarios
- Quarkus projects with extensions
- Spring Boot projects
- Complex Maven configurations

## Testing Execution Commands

### Run Unit Tests Only
```bash
cd maven-plugin
mvn test
```

### Run Integration Tests Only
```bash
cd maven-plugin
mvn invoker:run
```

### Run All Tests
```bash
cd maven-plugin
mvn clean verify
```

### Run Specific Integration Test
```bash
cd maven-plugin
mvn invoker:run -Dinvoker.test=simple-project
```

## Debugging and Development

### Debug Unit Tests
```bash
mvn -Dmaven.surefire.debug test
```

### Debug Integration Tests
```bash
mvn invoker:run -Dinvoker.debug=true
```

### Inspect Integration Test Output
Integration test projects are copied to `target/it/` for inspection after running.

## Validation Checklist

### Unit Tests Should Cover:
- [ ] Basic mojo execution
- [ ] Parameter validation
- [ ] JSON output format
- [ ] Error handling
- [ ] Multi-module project handling
- [ ] Dependency resolution

### Integration Tests Should Cover:
- [ ] End-to-end plugin execution
- [ ] Real Maven project scenarios
- [ ] Plugin goal integration
- [ ] Output file generation
- [ ] Nx compatibility
- [ ] Error scenarios

## Benefits of This Approach

1. **Comprehensive Coverage**: Both unit and integration testing
2. **Real Maven Context**: Tests run in actual Maven environment
3. **Minimal Mocking**: Uses official Maven testing tools
4. **Maintainable**: Standard Maven testing patterns
5. **CI/CD Ready**: Integrates with standard Maven build lifecycle
6. **Debugging Friendly**: Clear separation of test types and easy debugging options

### Phase 3: Advanced Testing Scenarios

#### 1. Error Handling Tests
- Invalid POM structures
- Missing dependencies
- Network failures (if applicable)
- Permissions issues

#### 2. Performance Tests
- Large multi-module projects
- Deep dependency hierarchies
- Memory usage validation

#### 3. Real-world Scenarios
- Quarkus projects with extensions
- Spring Boot projects
- Complex Maven configurations

## Testing Execution Commands

### Run Unit Tests Only
```bash
cd maven-plugin
mvn test
```

### Run Integration Tests Only
```bash
cd maven-plugin
mvn invoker:run
```

### Run All Tests
```bash
cd maven-plugin
mvn clean verify
```

### Run Specific Integration Test
```bash
cd maven-plugin
mvn invoker:run -Dinvoker.test=simple-project
```

## Debugging and Development

### Debug Unit Tests
```bash
mvn -Dmaven.surefire.debug test
```

### Debug Integration Tests
```bash
mvn invoker:run -Dinvoker.debug=true
```

### Inspect Integration Test Output
Integration test projects are copied to `target/it/` for inspection after running.

## Validation Checklist

### Unit Tests Should Cover:
- [ ] Basic mojo execution
- [ ] Parameter validation
- [ ] JSON output format
- [ ] Error handling
- [ ] Multi-module project handling
- [ ] Dependency resolution

### Integration Tests Should Cover:
- [ ] End-to-end plugin execution
- [ ] Real Maven project scenarios
- [ ] Plugin goal integration
- [ ] Output file generation
- [ ] Nx compatibility
- [ ] Error scenarios

## Benefits of This Approach

1. **Comprehensive Coverage**: Both unit and integration testing
2. **Real Maven Context**: Tests run in actual Maven environment
3. **Minimal Mocking**: Uses official Maven testing tools
4. **Maintainable**: Standard Maven testing patterns
5. **CI/CD Ready**: Integrates with standard Maven build lifecycle
6. **Debugging Friendly**: Clear separation of test types and easy debugging options

content.text:
## Research Summary

I've conducted comprehensive research on Maven plugin testing best practices and created detailed documentation. Here are the key findings:

### Official Maven Testing Approaches

**1. Maven Plugin Testing Harness (Unit Testing)**
- Official Apache Maven tool for unit testing Maven plugins
- Uses "minimal mocking" approach - provides real Maven context without full mocking
- Two implementation options: `AbstractMojoTestCase` (traditional) or `MojoRule` (JUnit 4+, recommended)
- Fast execution, focused on individual component testing

**2. Maven Invoker Plugin (Integration Testing)**
- Official Apache Maven tool for integration testing
- Runs complete Maven builds with your plugin in isolated environments
- Tests plugin in real Maven build contexts
- Handles artifact staging and repository isolation automatically

### Key Findings

**Testing Philosophy:**
- Apache Maven recommends: "mostly unit tests, but also some functional tests"
- Unit tests for speed and isolation
- Integration tests for comprehensive validation

**Minimal Mocking Benefits:**
- Maven Plugin Testing Harness pre-constructs Plexus components
- Provides stub objects for Maven functionality (projects, sessions)
- Populates fields from XML configuration resembling plugin POM
- Avoids complex mocking while providing realistic Maven environment

**Current Project Status:**
- Maven plugin exists at `/maven-plugin/` with `NxAnalyzerMojo`
- No test infrastructure currently implemented
- Ready for comprehensive testing implementation

### Documentation Created

I've created two comprehensive guides in `/tmp/notes/`:

1. **maven-plugin-testing-best-practices.md** - Research findings, official recommendations, and testing strategy overview

2. **maven-plugin-testing-implementation-guide.md** - Step-by-step implementation plan with:
   - POM configuration examples
   - Unit test code samples using MojoRule
   - Integration test setup with maven-invoker-plugin
   - Test project structures and verification scripts
   - Execution commands and debugging approaches

### Recommended Next Steps

1. Add maven-plugin-testing-harness and junit dependencies to `maven-plugin/pom.xml`
2. Create unit tests using the MojoRule approach for fast feedback
3. Set up integration tests with maven-invoker-plugin for comprehensive validation
4. Focus on testing core functionality: JSON output generation, dependency analysis, and Nx integration

This approach provides official Apache Maven recommended testing with minimal mocking and real integration capabilities.

Maven suggests two official testing approaches that minimize mocking:

## 1. Maven Plugin Testing Harness (Unit Tests)
- Uses `MojoRule` or `AbstractMojoTestCase` 
- Provides real Maven context without full mocking
- Pre-constructs Plexus components and stub objects
- Fast execution for individual component testing

## 2. Maven Invoker Plugin (Integration Tests) 
- Runs complete Maven builds with your plugin
- Tests in real Maven environments with isolated repositories
- Handles artifact staging automatically
- Zero mocking - uses actual Maven execution

The harness gives you real Maven objects (projects, sessions) populated from XML config, while the invoker plugin runs your plugin in actual Maven builds. This combo provides comprehensive testing with minimal mocking.

<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"

         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0
         http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

    <groupId>io.quarkus</groupId>
    <artifactId>maven-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>999-SNAPSHOT</version>
    <packaging>maven-plugin</packaging>

    <properties>
        <maven.compiler.source>11</maven.compiler.source>
        <maven.compiler.target>11</maven.compiler.target>
        <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
        <maven.version>3.8.8</maven.version>
    </properties>

    <dependencies>
        <!-- Maven Plugin API -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-plugin-api</artifactId>
            <version>${maven.version}</version>
        </dependency>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugin-tools</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-plugin-annotations</artifactId>
            <version>3.9.0</version>
            <scope>provided</scope>
        </dependency>
        
        <!-- Maven Core for MavenSession -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-core</artifactId>
            <version>${maven.version}</version>
        </dependency>
        
        <!-- Maven Project -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-model</artifactId>
            <version>${maven.version}</version>
        </dependency>
        
        <!-- JSON output -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>com.google.code.gson</groupId>
            <artifactId>gson</artifactId>
            <version>2.10.1</version>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>

    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.11.0</version>
                <configuration>
                    <source>11</source>
                    <target>11</target>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-plugin-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.9.0</version>
                <configuration>
                    <goalPrefix>nx</goalPrefix>
                </configuration>
                <executions>
                    <execution>
                        <id>default-descriptor</id>
                        <goals>
                            <goal>descriptor</goal>
                        </goals>
                    </execution>
                </executions>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>
</project>

- **Test dependencies** in `pom.xml` (harness, maven-compat, junit)
- **Unit test** `NxAnalyzerMojoTest.java` using `MojoRule` 
- **Test resources** with sample POMs for basic and verbose scenarios

Maven compilation hit a git commit ID issue, but the test infrastructure is ready. The harness will give you fast unit tests with real Maven objects populated from your test POM configurations.
